newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: AWB sees Japan as still in mkt for Australia wheat.
newsitem.headline: AWB sees Japan as still in mkt for Australia wheat.

text.p: The Australian Wheat Board (AWB) expects Japan will continue to buy Australian wheat to fulfil an agreement for the purchase of about 900,000 tonnes this year, an AWB spokesman said.
This was despite calls by the Food Agency of Japan, one of the AWB's largest customers, for a reduction in Australian wheat export prices.
"We've got a very good working relationship and are in daily contact with the Agency," an AWB spokesman told Reuters.
"We welcome any feedback on our prices. We're obviously concerned about how our customers feel," he said.
"We are in dialogue with them all the time. But we also try to get the best price for our growers, so we're also walking that tightrope," he said.
"They're obviously letting the world know how they feel," he said.
But the AWB was confident of achieving its agreement with Japan for the sale of about 900,000 tonnes of wheat, he said.
The AWB and Japan reach agreement each year which projects the approximate tonnage of wheat trade between the two countries. The agreement is not binding.
This year's agreement is for about 900,000 tonnes.
Japan bought 1.15 million tonnes of wheat from Australia in 1995/96 from a total of 13.22 million tonnes exported by the AWB in that year.
This made it Australia's fourth-largest customer in that year, after China, Hong Kong and Indonesia.
The AWB in the past has described Japan as its most stable customer.
The Food Agency of Japan said on Tuesday it would reduce wheat imports from Australia if prices were not reduced.
"We're known as a stable importer and have in the past bought wheat and barley even if prices fluctuated wildly," a Food Agency of Japan official was quoted by Reuters as saying in Tokyo.
"But we may be forced to become more market-oriented from now on," he said.
In the past two tenders, the agency did not buy Australian grain as it intended to because prices were too high, he said.
